In the commentary, after explaining the two concentrations, it says:
What dharma is life?
The verse says:
Life is precisely the life faculty.
The commentary says:
Why is it so?
In the Abhidharma Piá¹­aka, it says:
What is the life faculty?
It is the life of the three realms. This is not to be known.
What dharma is this life?
The verse says:
It is able to sustain the body, heat, and mental consciousness.
The commentary says:
This verse was spoken by the Buddha, the World-Honored One.

Life, heat, and mental consciousness, when these three abandon the body, the body that is abandoned is like dead wood without mind. Therefore, this dharma that is able to sustain heat and consciousness as the cause for the continuity of abiding is called life.
If that is so, what other dharma is able to sustain this life, this heat, and this consciousness, and in turn sustain this life?
If this is so, since these three dharmas arise by mutually supporting each other, which one ceases first?
Because of the cessation of this dharma, the other dharmas cease later.
If you maintain this, then the three dharmas should always arise and never cease.
This is not so. This life-force is supported by karma, because the continuity is born and abides according to how karma draws it.
If this is so, why not allow that heat and consciousness are supported by karma?
Do not maintain that all consciousness from beginning to end is retribution.
If this is so, then heat should be supported by karma, and consciousness should be supported by heat.
In this way, in the formless realm, consciousness should have no support, because heat and touch do not exist there.
This consciousness is supported by karma there. One cannot arbitrarily say that heat supports consciousness or that karma supports consciousness.
You have already admitted this.
What have you admitted?
Do not maintain that all consciousness from beginning to end is retribution.
Therefore, only life force holds the two together.
We also do not deny this, but it is not a separate real entity.
If so, what dharma do you establish as life force?
It is the duration of the homogeneous character of the group of dharmas attracted by the karma of the three realms.
Why is this?
This homogeneous character quickly follows the karma of the past and abides for the duration determined. The duration of this homogeneous character is called life force.
It is like the ripening time of rice and so forth.

Also, it is like the duration of an arrow shot. If someone holds that there is a separate virtue called speed that arises in the arrow, and the arrow moves until it falls due to following this virtue, for this person, due to the singularity and unobstructedness of this virtue, the difference in the time taken to reach other places quickly or slowly should not be established.
If you say that this virtue is obstructed by the wind,
this is not reasonable, because the arrow would either fall immediately or never fall, because the wind is no different.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas insist that this life force is a real entity.
Now, does death occur only through the exhaustion of life? Or does it occur through other factors as well?
In the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra, it is said:
There is death due to the exhaustion of life, and death due to the exhaustion of merit.
This has four cases.
The first case is when the karma that produces the life span is exhausted.
The second case is when the karma that produces wealth and pleasure is exhausted.
The third case is when both karmas are exhausted.
The fourth case is when one does not avoid inequality.
If life is exhausted and meritorious karma is exhausted, what power does one have over death?
In death due to the exhaustion of meritorious karma, the exhaustion of life is also so. Therefore, death due to the exhaustion of both is called death due to the exhaustion of both.
Moreover, in the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra, it is said:
Should it be said that life arises along with the continuum, or that it arises once and abides?
They answer:

Sentient beings in the desire realm who do not enter the concentration of non-perception or the concentration of non-thought should be said to have lifespans that arise in accordance with the continuity.
If they enter the two concentrations of observation, as well as sentient beings in the form and formless realms, it should be said that their lifespans arise once and then abide.
What meaning does this answer reveal?
If the support is harmed, the lifespan is also harmed.
This lifespan arises in accordance with the continuity. This is the meaning of the first sentence.
If the support of the lifespan cannot be harmed, it arises and then abides. This is the meaning of the second sentence.
The first sentence reveals that there are obstacles, the second sentence reveals that there are no obstacles. The teacher of KaÅ›mÄ«ra judges the meaning like this, therefore there is untimely death.
It is said in the sÅ«tra:
There are four kinds of bodies obtained by sentient beings. The first is the body of sentient beings, in which self-harm can be practiced, but harming others cannot be practiced.
This has four sentences.

Only those who die by their own hand are the gods who forget in play and the gods who are defiled by resentment. These two gods fall from their realm due to excessive joy and resentment, not by other conditions.
It is said that the Buddhas are also like this, dying by their own hand.
Only those who die by the hand of others are those in the womb and egg.
Both are killed in the desire realm.
Neither are killed in all intermediate existences, the form realm, the formless realm, and one part of the desire realm.

Like hell beings, Kuru people, those in the path of seeing, those in the concentration of compassion, those in the attainment of cessation, those in the attainment of non-perception, those who are kings, sages, and Buddhas, those who are prophesied by the Buddha,
Dharmaruci, Uttara, Jyotiska, the son of the elder, Yasa, Kumara, and Shiva, all the mothers of bodhisattvas who are reborn later, when the bodhisattva is in the womb;
the wheel-turning kings, the mothers of wheel-turning kings, when the king is in the womb.
In these cases, neither are killed.
Furthermore, how does the sÅ«tra say this?
Bhadramukha!
For what beings is self-harm not practiced, and harm by others also not practiced?
ÅšÄriputra!
Beings born in the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

The masters explain that in other concentrations and other formless realms, self-harm refers to the noble path of one's own stage, and harm by others refers to the preliminary concentration of a higher stage. In those, there are none of these two.
If so, then based on the noble path of other stages, it should be considered harm by others.
If not, what is the meaning?
Either by taking the latter it also reveals the former, or by taking the former it also reveals the latter.
Taking the former and also revealing the latter is like the sÅ«tra saying:
Like the BrahmakÄyika gods, this is the first heaven of blissful rebirth.
Taking the latter and also revealing the former is like the sÅ«tra saying:
Like the Ä€bhÄsvara gods, this is the second heaven of blissful rebirth.
In that sÅ«tra, the meaning of like is clearly metaphorical, therefore that meaning is acceptable there, namely taking the former along with the latter, taking the latter along with the former.
Why is it so?
It is because this is the method of metaphor, by which one type is illustrated and the rest can be understood by analogy.
In ÅšÄriputra's question, there is no like statement, therefore that sÅ«tra cannot be cited as evidence for this sÅ«tra.
If you insist that the illustration is the meaning of like, then this sÅ«tra should not have the word like.
The sÅ«tra says:
There are sentient beings whose bodies are different and whose perceptions are different, like humans and some gods.
Therefore, you should know that like is only for illustration, not for metaphor. Let us not speak too much.
Having explained lifespan,
the verse says:
There are also four conditioned characteristics: arising, abiding, aging, and impermanence.
The commentary says:
The conditioned dharmas are only these four characteristics. If there are these four characteristics in a dharma, one should know that this dharma is conditioned.
The opposite of the above is unconditioned.
Here, arising is able to give rise to this dharma, abiding is able to establish this dharma, aging is able to change this dharma, and impermanence is able to extinguish this dharma. Is it not so?
As the sutra says:
There are three kinds of conditioned dharmas, the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas].
If speaking in full, in the sutra one should speak of a fourth characteristic.
This sutra does not speak of it.
What characteristic?
Namely, abiding.

If so, what dharma is spoken of in this sutra as abiding and changing?ğŸ”½This abiding and changing is an alternate name for aging, just as arising is an alternate name for birth, and cessation is an alternate name for impermanence.
Abiding and changing are also alternate names for aging.

If dharmas are able to arise, they only function as conditioned dharmas in the world. These dharmas are said to have the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas] in the sÅ«tras in order to arouse disgust in others.
Why is this?

Arising is able to lead conditioned dharmas from the future world and cause them to enter the present world. Aging and impermanence are able to diminish their power and send them from the present world into the past world.
It is like a person in a dense forest with three enemies. One is able to pull them out of the forest into the open, one is able to diminish their strength, and one is able to end their life.

The three characteristics of conditioned [dharmas] are also like this. Enduring embraces and includes conditioned dharmas, as if they were inseparable. Therefore, this enduring is not established as a characteristic of conditioned [dharmas].
Moreover, there are unconditioned dharmas that abide in their own characteristics, so the characteristic of enduring is confused.
Other masters hold that in this sÅ«tra, enduring and aging are combined into one, and therefore three characteristics are mentioned.
What is the use of this?
This abiding is the basis for attachment to conditioned things, therefore the Buddha manifests this abiding.
Just as a prosperous king's position is accompanied by calamities, in order to prevent others from giving rise to attachment to it.
Therefore conditioned things definitely have four characteristics.
Moreover, since there are four characteristics such as birth for conditioned things, are there further separate characteristics such as birth for these characteristics?
It is said:
There are.
The verse states:
The characteristics of those characteristics such as birth.
The commentary explains:
The word those refers to the four fundamental characteristics. Because dharmas have fundamental characteristics, they become conditioned.
The fundamental characteristics are also like this. Because of the secondary characteristics, they become conditioned.

Therefore the fundamental characteristics are established to have four secondary characteristics, namely the birth of birth, the abiding of abiding, the aging of aging, and the impermanence of impermanence.
If this is so, then each of the characteristics should have four characteristics, resulting in an infinite regress, because the secondary characteristics establish separate characteristics again.
There is no infinite regress.
Why is this?
The verse states:
The eight and one dharmas are events.
The explanation is as follows:
These characteristics have events in eight dharmas.
What are called events?
Causal efficacy and human effort.
The characteristics of arising, arising of arising, etc. only have events in one dharma.
How is this so?
All conditioned dharmas, when arising, take their own substance as the ninth, together with the fundamental characteristics and the secondary characteristics, eight in total.
Among them, arising, apart from its own substance, can give rise to eight dharmas. The arising of arising only gives rise to the fundamental arising.
It is like a hen that can give birth to many chicks, or one chick, or two chicks.
Abiding, apart from its own substance, can establish eight dharmas. Abiding of abiding only establishes the fundamental abiding.
Aging and impermanence should be combined with the previous meaning in the same way.
Therefore there is no infinite regress.
The SautrÄntika school says:
This doctrine is precisely the refutation of space as an event.
Why is this?
Because birth and other dharmas are not real entities, just as you have divided them.
How do we know they are not real entities?
Because there are innumerable proofs.

Among the real entities of the four characteristics, there is not a single means of valid cognition, such as direct perception, inference, or scriptural authority, as there is for dharmas such as form.
If that is so, then why does the sutra say:
The conditioned dharmas, whose arising can be known, and whose passing away and abiding can be known.
Alas, my friend!
You are able to recite the GÄndhÄrÄ«, but you do not understand the meaning of the GÄndhÄrÄ«.
The World-Honored Buddha said that the meaning is the standard, not the words.
What is the meaning?
Ignorant ordinary beings, blinded by ignorance, grasp at the continuity of conditioned dharmas as I and mine, and give rise to attachment to them.

The World-Honored One, in order to eliminate their attachment, wishing to show that the continuity of conditioned phenomena is the characteristic of the conditioned and the characteristic of dependent arising, thus spoke this sutra.

The sÅ«tra says there are three kinds of conditioned dharmas and characteristics of conditioned [dharmas], but this is not to show that the four characteristics of a single moment of conditioned [dharmas] are real entities.
If a dharma cannot be known, it is not suitable to be established as a characteristic.
Therefore, this sÅ«tra says that if the arising of conditioned dharmas can be known, and so forth.

The sÅ«tra speaks of the repeated name of conditioned [dharmas] in order to make others know that these characteristics manifest the nature of conditioned [dharmas], and should not be like this to show that the category of conditioned dharmas exists, therefore the four characteristics are established.

It is like a white egret in the water, and the characteristics of a good or bad maiden. Here, the initial arising of the continuum is called birth, the final passing away is called cessation, the flow of this continuum is called abiding, and the difference between before and after is called abiding and changing.
The World-Honored Buddha, in order to illustrate this meaning, spoke about Nanda:
Nanda!
Good man!
You know well how feelings arise, you know well how feelings abide, and you know well how feelings fade away and cease.
Here, a verse says:
Birth refers to the beginning of continuity, cessation is the cutting off of continuity, abiding is the continuity of existence,
Abiding and change are the differences between the previous and subsequent moments of this continuity.
Moreover, a verse says:
What was previously non-existent is called birth, abiding is the impermanence of continuity,
The continuity is cut off and abides differently, the previous and subsequent moments of the continuity are different.
Moreover, a verse says:
If a dharma ceases in a moment, apart from abiding it would immediately cease,
This is always ceasing, therefore it is unreasonable to distinguish abiding.
Therefore, continuity is definitely abiding.
If one grasps this meaning, then the explanation of the Abhidharma Piá¹­aka accords with reason.
The Abhidharma Piá¹­aka says:
What is abiding?
It is the non-cessation of arisen conditioned dharmas.
What does this mean?
Why is it so?
Because dharmas that cease in a moment, once arisen, do not not cease.
The *PrajÃ±ÄpradÄ«pa ÅšÄstra says:
What is called birth in one mind?
It means initial arising.
What is called cessation?
It means death.
What is called abiding and changing?
It means aging.
In this treatise, it is just the same for a single aggregate continuity of mind. In this mind, it is as before.
There is another explanation: in each moment of conditioned dharmas, this meaning is also established as a separate entity apart from discrimination.
How is it established?

For each moment, what has not yet existed is called birth, what has existed and no longer exists is called cessation, the moments that are successively earlier and later are called abiding, and their dissimilarity is called abiding and changing.
If so, there are dharmas that are born but do not change. How is this?
Although it is like this, it is not without difference.
How is this known?

Because there is a difference in the time of falling for things like vajra when thrown, not thrown, thrown with strong force, and thrown with weak force, the difference in the transformation of those four elements is established.
All conditioned dharmas do not differ greatly, although they appear different.

If so, the last moment of sound and light, and the last six sense bases at the time of nirvana, do not have the characteristics of abiding and changing because there is no subsequent moment. Therefore, establishing these as characteristics does not cover all conditioned dharmas.
If abiding is not mentioned as a characteristic of conditioned dharmas, what is meant by abiding and changing?
If a dharma has abiding, this dharma must have abiding and changing. Therefore, establishing non-abiding does not cover all.
If briefly explained in this sÅ«tra, the characteristics of conditioned dharmas revealed by the World-Honored One in this sÅ«tra must be like this. The sÅ«tra says:
What are the characteristics of conditioned [dharmas]?
If something did not exist before but exists now, and having existed does not exist again, this continuity of dharmas is called abiding;
this continuity being different before and after is called abiding and changing. What need is there to establish birth, etc. in this?
How can this dharma, which is the characterized, be established as the characteristic?
The characteristics of a great person are not different from a great person. How can they be established as characteristics?
The hump, dewlap, hooves, and horns of a cow are its characteristics. They are not different from the cow. How can they be established as characteristics?
It is like solidity, etc., which are the characteristics of earth, etc. They are not different from earth.
Moreover, it is like the characteristic of rising upward being the characteristic of smoke. By this characteristic, one knows smoke from a distance. This characteristic is not different from smoke.
The principle of the characteristics of conditioned phenomena is also like this.
The characteristics of conditioned phenomena such as form, etc. are not conditioned by existence.

If one has already distinguished their intrinsic nature, but has not yet understood the characteristics of prior non-existence, subsequent existence, and continuity, therefore by these characteristics, the nature of conditioned phenomena cannot be characterized.

Moreover, the characteristics of conditioned phenomena are not separate real entities. If one forcefully grasps that the characteristics such as arising, etc. are separate real entities, what other unreasonable meaning is there that should be more serious than this?
Why is it so?
This one dharma at one time is in the process of arising, abiding, aging, and ceasing.
What is meant by in the process?
Because the characteristics arise together.
This is not so, because of the difference in function. That which is in the process of arising is in the future and obtains its function.
How do we know?
Because a dharma that has already arisen cannot be produced again.
If a dharma that is being produced has already arisen, abiding, etc. are in the present and obtain their function.
At that time the dharma is arising, not abiding, aging, or ceasing.
This meaning should be considered together:
Do future dharmas exist or not?
Later, can they be produced or not?
This meaning should be established.
If this dharma exists and its function of producing is in it, how can this dharma be established as future?
It should be said that this dharma's future characteristic has already ceased and its substance has already arisen.
How is it established as present?

The characteristics of the present should also be explained. Abiding, etc. are all included in the function. In one moment, this dharma has the characteristics of abiding, aging, and ceasing together.
Why is this?
At that time, abiding firmly establishes this dharma, at that time aging changes this dharma, at that time impermanence causes this dharma to cease.
At one time, is this dharma abiding, aging, or ceasing?
Other people say:
The functions of the characteristics such as abiding are not simultaneous. For this person, the meaning of momentary cessation is lost.
If you say that I establish a moment, and the functions of these four characteristics are called a moment,
then abiding arises together with the other two. First, it temporarily establishes the dharma, aging does not change it, and impermanence does not cause it to cease.
How can this meaning be established?
Because the power of action is strong.
How does abiding have strong power?
It is like impermanence ceasing, where abiding and the original dharma, having already arisen, cannot give rise to their function again, just as arising does not give rise to its function again.
This meaning is reasonable.
Why is it so?
It is reasonable that the dharma that should arise, having already been brought to the present, does not need to be brought again.
This dharma, having been established by abiding, can be permanently established.
If it cannot be established, then it is not reasonable.
What obstructs it?
Aging and impermanence are the obstructions.
If these two have power, they should be established first.
If the power of abiding has already ceased, these two also do not abide.
How can the original dharma give rise to its function?
Where does it give rise to its function?
What other separate function can these two perform?
Why is it so?
Because it is subsumed by abiding.

The dharma only arises but does not cease. If it is abandoned by abiding, it definitely does not abide. This is precisely the cessation of this dharma. Therefore, these two have no function to perform.
This meaning is hypothetically acceptable.
This one dharma has already arisen and not yet ceased, and is established as abiding. Cessation is called impermanence and aging. It cannot be established in one dharma in all aspects.
Why is this?
Aging means being different before and after, and changing. This dharma should not become a different category from this dharma.
Here a verse is spoken:
If there is no aging as before, if it is different, it is not the previous dharma.
Therefore, the characteristic of aging cannot be established in one dharma.
Other schools say:
The cause of reaching cessation is impermanence, which can cause the cessation of the original dharma.
In their school, this meaning should be reached: When taking a laxative, the gods come and cause it to work. What need is there to distinguish impermanence?
From this, the cause of cessation itself is sufficient to establish cessation.

The mind and mental factors cease due to faith in the momentariness of the mind and mental factors. The characteristic of impermanence of the mind and mental factors is not observed due to the cause of cessation. Therefore, abiding and impermanence do not function together at different times.
One dharma at one time should be established as both abiding and ceasing. Therefore, based on continuity, the World-Honored One spoke of the characteristics of conditioned dharmas.
If this meaning is relied upon, that sÅ«tra is well established.
Moreover, if arising in the future can give rise to dharmas that should arise, why do not all future dharmas arise simultaneously?
For this reason, the verse says:
Arising can give rise to what should arise, not apart from causes and conditions.
The commentary says:
Because arising cannot give rise to [dharmas] apart from the combination of causes and conditions, future dharmas do not arise simultaneously.

If so, we see that this is the function of causes and conditions. If there is a combination, arising exists. If there is no combination, arising does not exist. Therefore, arising cannot give rise to dharmas that should arise. Thus, one should admit that only causes and conditions can give rise [to dharmas].
If everything exists, how can it be known?
It means that when this dharma has already arisen, this cognition should not exist. If arising truly does not exist,ğŸ”½then.
Moreover, the expression associated with would also not be established, referring to what arises in the realm of form.
If it were as you assert, one should say form in the realm of form, up to aging and death as appropriate.
In that case, therefore, you should also accept the meaning of non-self in the same way, as well as number, each, combination, separation, this, that, existence, and so forth.
Such things, which are established by non-Buddhists as truly existing entities, you should also believe and accept.
Why is this?
Because in order to establish one, large, separate, dispersed, self, other, existing entity, and so forth, cognition is necessary.
And because the expression associated with is established, as in saying aggregate of form.
How is this expression associated with established as the intrinsic nature of form?

Therefore, arising and so forth are only nominally established. In order to show the meaning of existence where there was previously non-existence, it is provisionally said to be arising. This arising did not exist previously.

Now, the characteristics of the conditioned have many kinds, in order to distinguish the differences in kinds, it is said in accordance with form that arising is the characteristic of the conditioned, meaning to let one know that this arising is only form and not the other three characteristics, just as it is said that the fragrance of sandalwood and so forth is the essence of the stone.
The other three characteristics of duration, change, and impermanence should be understood in the same way as arising, in accordance with reason.
If a dharma can be born apart from the characteristic of arising, why do unconditioned dharmas such as space not arise?
You understand that non-arising means that which did not exist before now exists, this is called arising.
Since the unconditioned has always existed, how can it arise?
If it is due to the inherent nature of dharmas, you allow that all dharmas are unarisen, and in this case all are indeed unarisen.
Why not accept this?
Just as all conditioned dharmas have arising in common, there are other causes and conditions for arising, and no dharma has the ability [to arise by itself].
In the same way, all causes and conditions for the unconditioned have no ability [to give rise to the unconditioned].
Because arising is not the same, the VaibhÄá¹£ikas say:
The four characteristics of birth, etc. are real and separate entities.
Why is this?

One should not abandon the scriptures because of the objections of others, just as one does not refrain from planting wheat because there are deer, or because there are many flies one does not eat fruit.
Therefore, one should cultivate the antidotes to faults in accordance with the siddhÄnta.
Having explained the eight characteristics,
what are the collections of names, etc.?
A verse says:
The collections of names, phrases, and syllables are called the general assemblies of speech.
The commentary says:
Among them, a name is what is established as a designation, such as form, sound, etc.
A phrase is what is established as speech, able to accomplish what one wishes to say according to the measure, such as All conditioned things are impermanent, etc.
If by this speech the matter is made to appear in a timely and appropriate manner, this speech is called a phrase, as a verse says:
Good friends meet at one time.
A syllable is a meaningless text, such as a, Ä, i, Ä«, etc.
Is it not so?
Letters are the divisions of written documents. The ruler does not create letters to manifest written documents, but creates written documents to manifest letters.
If one does not hear the explanation of letters, how can these letters be known through the expedient of writing?
In order to make them known, written documents are established. Therefore, letters are not non-written document names. These are called the three collections of names, phrases, and letters.
Among them, the collection of names is like form, sound, smell, taste, touch, etc.
The collection of phrases is like all conditioned things are impermanent, all dharmas are without self, nirvana is quiescent, and so forth.
The collection of letters is like ka, kha, ga, gha, etc. Is it not so?
These collections of names, etc., have speech as their essence, which is the nature of sound belonging to the essence of form. How can they be said to be mental factors not associated with form?
This dharma does not have speech as its nature.
Why is it so?
Sound is precisely speech. One cannot understand the meanings through sound alone.
How can one understand?
Sound gives rise to names, and names can manifest meanings.
One does not merely call sound speech. If the meaning can be understood through this sound, then that sound is called speech.
Through what sound can the meaning be understood?
If the speaker has already established a definite rule regarding the meaning, like the sound cow.
Regarding the nine meanings, a definite rule has been established. As the NyÄyasÅ«tra says in verse:
Words, directions, earth, light, cow, vajra, eye, heaven, and water,
Regarding these nine meanings, the wise ones say the word 'cow.'
If one holds the view that names can manifest meanings, then one should also believe and accept this meaning.

If a name is already established as indicating a meaning, if a meaning is indicated by a name, this function can be accomplished by sound alone indicating a meaning. What need is there to establish a real separate entity called name?
This meaning cannot be known.
How does sound give rise to a name?
Is it said to give rise to a name in order to produce sound, or is it said to give rise to in order to manifest a name?
If it is said to give rise to, because language has sound as its nature, it should give rise to all names, which have only sound as their essence.
Moreover, this is a distinction of sound.
As you allow, it should only be able to manifest meaning.
If it is said to manifest, because language has sound as its nature, it should manifest all names, which have only sound as their essence.
Moreover, this is a distinction of sound.
As you allow, it should only be able to manifest meaning. What need is there to grasp that names are separate entities?
Moreover, sounds do not accumulate, and a single dharma arises in parts.
This is unreasonable. If you hold that language can produce names, how can it produce names?
How can one observe past teaching forms in a moment?
The last moment of teaching form can produce non-teaching form.

If so, because names arise from the last sound, if a person only hears the last sound, that person should be able to understand the meaning.ğŸ”½If you hold that sound produces letters, and letters produce names, the previous objection still applies here, because letters do not accumulate.
If you say that sound manifests letters, the previous objection still applies here, because letters are different from sound.
Even a wise person with a calm mind cannot distinguish them based on different characteristics, so it is not tenable to hold that sound can produce and manifest letters.
Moreover, if you allow that names must always be associated with meanings, like birth and so forth,
Here, the meanings of past and future do not correspond to the present.
How can a father arbitrarily give a child a name?
How can a name arise together with unconditioned dharmas?
Therefore, this view is not a proper method.
The Buddha has said:
Based on names, verses are composed, and verses are created.

Here, the fixed dharma established for meaning is called sound, and the various adornments of names are called verses. This adornment is based on names and is the difference in arrangement, not a separate entity, like the sequence of things and the sequence of mind.

Moreover, only in terms of letters is it distinguished that there is a separate entity. The collective total of letters is called the aggregate of names, the aggregate of phrases, and the aggregate of letters. This is only a provisional designation without a real function.
The VaibhÄá¹£ikas say that there are actually non-associated compositional factors as their nature, namely the aggregates of names, phrases, and letters.
Why is it so?
Not all dharmas can be fully understood through conceptualization and reflection.
In which realm are the non-associated formative forces such as name-collection associated?
Are they names of sentient beings or non-sentient beings?
Are they born from retribution, born from development, or born from outflow?
Are they wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate?
These questions should be answered.
The verse says:
In the desire and form realms, they are associated with sentient beings, born from outflow, and indeterminate.
The explanation says:

Furthermore, there is karma whose only fruition is one dharma-entry, namely, life as its fruition.
If an action produces the retribution of the mental faculty, this action produces two sense-fields as retribution, namely the mental faculty and the sense-field of factors.
In the same way, if an action produces the retribution of the sense-field of tangibility, it is also like this.
If an action produces the retribution of the body sense-field, this action produces three sense-fields as retribution, namely the body, tangibility, and the sense-field of factors.
In the same way, it is also like this for form, smell, and taste.
If an action produces the retribution of the eye faculty, this action produces four sense-fields as retribution, namely the eye, body, tangibility, and the sense-field of factors.
In the same way, it is also like this for the ear, nose, and tongue.
There are actions that produce the retribution of five, six, seven, eight, nine, ten, or eleven sense-fields.
Why is this?
Because there are two kinds of actions: some have many actions and one retribution, while others have one action and many retributions.
It is like external seeds, some of which have many seeds and one fruit, while others have one seed and one fruit.

It is possible that the result of actions of one period ripens in three periods, but it is impossible that the result of actions of three periods ripens in one period, because the result should not be less than the cause. Thus, an action of one moment can have a result of many moments.
This meaning is not inverted. The result does not ripen simultaneously with the action, nor does it ripen immediately after.
Why is this?
Because the subsequent moments are drawn by the condition of the immediately preceding moment.
The result of retribution ripens at the end of the continuity of moments that are observed in sequence.
Furthermore, in which periods are these six causes definitely located?
Their definite periods have already been shown by the meaning, but have not yet been explained by words. Therefore, it should be further stated and explained.

The commentary says:
These two causes, if in the past or present, then become causes. If in the future, they do not become causes. The principle that can prove this meaning has already been explained above.

Having explained the six causes,
what dharmas are their effects?
Based on this, they become causes.
The verse states:
Conditioned and cessation through discrimination are effects.
The commentary explains:
What are the dharmas that are effects?
All conditioned dharmas and cessation through discrimination. The Abhidharma treatise states it this way.
If so, unconditioned dharmas should have causes because of being effects.
If a dharma takes this as its effect, that dharma becomes a cause, and then it should produce an effect.
If a dharma is conditioned, cause and effect can be established.
The verse states:
Unconditioned [dharmas] are neither causes nor effects.
The commentary explains:
Unconditioned dharmas cannot be established as causes or effects.
Why is this?
Because they are not the six causes and not the five effects.
Why do you not admit that the holy path is the homogeneous cause of the cessation due to deliberation?
Because it is established as the homogeneous cause by reason of its ability to prevent the arising of dharmas that should arise.
The unconditioned has no arising. Therefore, it cannot be a cause of the unconditioned.
If that is so, what is the effect of the unconditioned?
What is the meaning of effect?
It is the effect of the path, because it is attained by the power of the path.
If that is so, only attainment is the effect of the path, because the path has the ability to attain. Cessation due to deliberation is not.
There is another meaning. The holy path has the ability to attain.
There is another meaning. The path has the ability to attain cessation due to deliberation.
How can the ability to cause arising be in attainment?
How can the ability to cause attainment be in cessation due to deliberation?
Therefore, the holy path is not the direct cause of cessation due to deliberation, and cessation due to deliberation is not the direct effect of the holy path, but it is the dominant effect.
How can the unconditioned be the homogeneous cause?
Because it does not obstruct the arising of others, it becomes the homogeneous cause.
This dharma has no effect, because the liberated dharma has no function in taking or giving effects.

All that can produce form is impermanent.
If form arises depending on impermanent causes and conditions, how can form be permanent?
Up to consciousness, it is the same.
